sentences: Linda Martell (born Thelma Bynem; June 4, 1941) is an American singer.
During the 1960s, the group recorded a handful of R&B singles and sang alongside other black performers.
This led to an introduction to producer Shelby Singleton, who signed her to his Nashville label in 1969.
The same year, the label released her country cover of "Color Him Father."
The song became a charting single on the Billboard charts and her debut album followed in 1970.
She then retired from the country music industry in 1974 following a lack of success.
Over the next several decades, she lived in various states and continued performing music.
To make a living, she worked in public education and returned to South Carolina in the 1990s.
Early years ==
Thelma Bynem was born June 4, 1941  as one of five children born to Clarence and Willie May Bynem in Leesville, South Carolina.
Thelma Bynem was born June 4, 1941  as one of five children born to Clarence and Willie May Bynem in Leesville, South Carolina.
Her father was a sharecropper while her mother worked many hours at a chicken slaughterhouse.
To avoid helping with sharecropping duties, Martell learned to make dinners for her family when she was seven years old.
"Until we got into our teens we knew country music and that was it," she told the Courier-Post in 1998.

sentences: On May 15, 1969, Martell signed a management contract with Rayner and signed with Singleton's Plantation record label the next day.
On May 15, 1969, Martell signed a management contract with Rayner and signed with Singleton's Plantation record label the next day.
The song was issued as Martell's first Plantation single in July 1969.
Its follow-up was Martell's interpretation of "Before the Next Teardrop Falls," which was later covered by Freddy Fender.
Martell's version reached number 33 on the Billboard country chart in 1970.
In August 1970, her debut album was released on Plantation Records titled Color Me Country.
The album was reviewed favorably by Billboard in 1970, which found her country singing style to be authentic.
In later years, AllMusic rated the record three and a half stars with similar commentary.
She soon made television appearances on The Bill Anderson Show and Hee Haw in 1970.
In May 1970, Rayner sued her because he believed he deserved a higher commission.
It ruined my reputation in country music," she recalled in 2020.
After several more years of limited success, Martell ultimately chose to retire from the Nashville music industry.
